animals.name: European Hedgehog
animals.alt: A hedgehog walking through short grass
animals.summary: A small nocturnal insect-eater that may arrive at rescue centres due to injury, dehydration, or habitat fragmentation.
animals.detail: Hedgehogs rely on connected green spaces and quiet nesting areas. In urban and suburban settings, they can struggle with barriers between gardens and reduced insect food sources.
animals.helpTip: Leave a 13cm x 13cm gap in fences or gates (a “hedgehog highway”) so they can move between gardens safely.

animals.name: European Badger
animals.summary: A strong, social mammal that lives in family groups and uses underground setts with multiple entrances.
animals.detail: Badgers are mainly active at night and can be sensitive to disturbance near sett sites. They play an important role in woodland ecosystems through digging and foraging activity.
animals.helpTip: Never block or disturb sett entrances. Keep dogs on leads near woodland edges where setts may be present.

animals.name: Barn Owl
animals.alt: A barn owl perched on a branch
animals.summary: Often brought in following vehicle collisions, storms, or when young birds are found grounded and unable to fly well.
animals.detail: Barn owls hunt low over grassland and field margins, relying heavily on healthy small mammal populations. Quiet, dark roost spaces are important during recovery.
animals.helpTip: If you find an injured owl or bird of prey, contact a wildlife rescue immediately—avoid feeding, as the wrong diet can cause harm.

animals.name: Red Fox
animals.alt: A red fox looking towards the camera
animals.summary: Highly adaptable and found in both rural and urban areas; young cubs can become separated after disturbance.
animals.detail: Foxes are opportunistic feeders and may approach residential areas at night. Young foxes are commonly misunderstood—many are healthy and simply exploring.
animals.helpTip: If you see a cub alone, observe from a distance first. Adults may be nearby and return later—only intervene if there are clear signs of injury.

animals.name: Eurasian Otter
animals.alt: An otter near the water’s edge
animals.summary: A semi-aquatic mammal that depends on clean waterways; threats include road traffic near rivers and water pollution.
animals.detail: Otters require connected river corridors with good cover and healthy fish stocks. Even small amounts of pollution can damage habitats and reduce food availability.
animals.helpTip: Keep waterways clean: dispose of litter responsibly, and report signs of pollution (foam, strong odours, dead fish) to local authorities.

animals.name: Red Squirrel
animals.alt: A red squirrel holding food on a tree branch
animals.summary: A native woodland squirrel under pressure from habitat change and competition; conservation focuses on protecting suitable woodland areas.
animals.detail: Red squirrels thrive in conifer and mixed woodland where food sources and nesting sites are stable. Local conservation programmes focus on habitat protection and monitoring.
animals.helpTip: Use squirrel-friendly feeders in appropriate areas and avoid leaving food that attracts pests. Report injured squirrels to a local wildlife rescue.
